etymologies: late Middle English: contraction of obsolete sithence, or from dialect sin (both from dialect sithen ‘thereupon, afterward, ever since’)

notes.text: When using since as a causal conjunction to mean ‘because’ or ‘given that,’ be aware that in some contexts or constructions the word may be construed as referring to time. For example, in the sentence, Since Mrs. Jefferson moved to Baltimore in the 1990s, she was not aware of the underlying complexities, it is not clear, especially at the beginning, whether since means ‘because’ or ‘from the time when.’ It is often better to simply say ‘because,’ if that is the intended meaning

definitions: in the intervening period between (the time mentioned) and the time under consideration, typically the present

examples.text: she hasn't spoken to him since last year
a lot has changed in the industry since then
the worst property slump since the war

shortDefinitions: in intervening period between time mentioned and time under consideration

notes.text: When using since as a causal conjunction to mean ‘because’ or ‘given that,’ be aware that in some contexts or constructions the word may be construed as referring to time. For example, in the sentence, Since Mrs. Jefferson moved to Baltimore in the 1990s, she was not aware of the underlying complexities, it is not clear, especially at the beginning, whether since means ‘because’ or ‘from the time when.’ It is often better to simply say ‘because,’ if that is the intended meaning

definitions: from a time in the past until the time under consideration, typically the present

examples.text: I've felt better since I've been here
ever since the film hit cinemas in 1996, fans have been wondering whether a sequel would finally get the go-ahead

shortDefinitions: from time in past until now

examples.text: delegates were delighted, since better protection of rhino reserves will help protect other rare species

synonyms.text: in view of the fact that

notes.text: When using since as a causal conjunction to mean ‘because’ or ‘given that,’ be aware that in some contexts or constructions the word may be construed as referring to time. For example, in the sentence, Since Mrs. Jefferson moved to Baltimore in the 1990s, she was not aware of the underlying complexities, it is not clear, especially at the beginning, whether since means ‘because’ or ‘from the time when.’ It is often better to simply say ‘because,’ if that is the intended meaning

examples.text: she ran away on Friday and we haven't seen her since
the couple divorced in 2012 and he has since remarried
the settlement had vanished long since
